instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U9200</CHIP> shorted
threads.message:
Clean board, <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> looked burned in one corner, after removing <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> short was still there, so after injecting 2.5V <CHIP>U9200</CHIP> barely gets hot, but that is the only place that gets hot, this is not a full short, only 0.010 in diode mode.

Is there a way to replace this NAND chips from other boards? 

I don't have a problem with the reball etc, but I don't have the same exact board in this case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U9200</CHIP> shorted
threads.message:
You may need to replace all NAND chips, from exactly same donor board model.
SSD ROM and controller may also need to change them.
And must pass through DFU, if possible.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U9200</CHIP> shorted
threads.message:
can I know from 2informaticos you which are in component number of the ssd ROM and Controller?
does it work if the machine has less or more capacity?
